summary: IL-4 signaling determines the state of macrophage activation and pattern of RV-induced exacerbation in mice with allergic airways disease. IL-4 receptor knockout (IL-4R KO) mice were sensitized and challenged with OVA and inoculated with RV1B or sham HeLa cell lysate. OVA-treated IL-4R KO mice show neutrophilic airway inflammation constituting a model of allergic, type 1 cytokine-driven neutrophilic asthma. in mice with allergic airways inflammation, IL-4/IL-13 signaling determines macrophage activation state and the response to subsequent RV infection. RV increased eosinophilic inflammation in ovalbumin (OVA)-sensitized and -challenged mice. CD206 is increased in the asthmatic patients and correlates with the severity of asthma.
